places_with_reviews.name: Aligarh Fort
places_with_reviews.address: W3G5+5W6, Masud Nagar, Qila, Aligarh, Uttar Pradesh 202001, India

reviews.text: It is a matter of great pride that a  5 🌟 category hotel has come to our Aligarh.Hotel Name Fortune Park, Aligarh, ITC Group.

Aligarh Fort, also known as ‘Aligarh Quila’, ‘Baunasaur Quila’ or ‘Ramgarh Quila’, is amongst chief attractions of the destination.

The fort was built by Muhammad, son of Governor Umar in 1525 during the reign of Ibrahim Lodhi. It is located on a hill with steep ravines on all sides of about 32 feet.

The polygonal construction having bastions at each angle is the highlight of the ancient testimony

Aligarh qila or bone chor ka qila was built in 1524-25 by ibrahim lodhi, however now only the ruined remains of the fort are present but alot of greenery, beautiful and colourful trees are present inside the fort area alongwith a botanical garden under control of aligarh muslim university.
Here you can find birds and animals like peacocks, ferrets, koel birds, etc and the ambience is really calm and peaceful.
Reaching the main ruins of fort and on top of the fort area is not easy as the trails which leads to them are covered in thorns, bushes and steep inclines.
There is no entry ticket so anyone can visit it which makes it a weekend destination.
A large parking area is also present here.
So if you are a nature lover then this is a must visit place.
The only place to visit in Aligarh, but due to negligence the fort is losing its charm...

If are looking for peace, just go there and take a deep breath.. you will find peace and satisfaction... Although it's one of the silent places I ever visited... But if you are planning go there kindly visit in afternoon and there is one dargah also for the devotional ones..
Yes it's far from Aligarh dense area but a nice place to visit...
I remember that it's just located near faculty of law, Aligarh

places_with_reviews.name: Centenary Gate, Aligarh Muslim University
places_with_reviews.address: University Rd, Purani Chungi, AMU Campus, Aligarh, Uttar Pradesh 202001, India

reviews.text: I am writing to express my sincere appreciation for the remarkable institution that is Aligarh Muslim University (AMU). It is not merely a university but a bastion of knowledge, diversity, and cultural richness. AMU's commitment to academic excellence is evident in its storied history and the countless success stories of its graduates. The university's emphasis on fostering critical thinking and research has not only shaped individuals but has contributed significantly to the intellectual landscape of our nation. One cannot overlook the unique environment that AMU provides a melting pot of cultures, where students from various backgrounds come together to learn and grow. This cultural diversity is not just a feature but a strength that prepares students for the globalized world, instilling in them values of tolerance and understanding.

The Centenary Gate at AMU is a beloved landmark that represents the university’s long history and academic success. Its beautiful design and historical importance make it a favorite spot for students and visitors. Walking through the gate fills you with pride and a sense of belonging to AMU’s community. It’s a reminder of the university’s dedication to excellence and welcoming atmosphere.

I visited AMU Campus for the entrance examination. All the students are so helpful and of friendly nature. They have offered rooms to sit & study as I have reached earlier. The vibes of the Campus are just amazing. Overall it's a very marvelous place
This is a one of the gate to enter the university campus from purani chungi. This gate has built on the completion of 💯 years.

So beautiful ❤️❤️🤩
I went with my family and had a great time ☺️
You can also enjoy coffee or chai from the Dhaba ☺️🤩

Famous Naqvi Park is also named Rajkeey Uddhan Jawahar Park. It’s a vast park with lush green vegetation and giant old trees, with Gulab Bari, fountains and many other attractions. Naqvi Park is popular among joggers and morning walkers. People also throng this park with families on their leisure time.
One of the only best place for workout with exercise manual machines for better health and fitness.

A must visit mosque in Aligarh, such a soothing feeling.
You will be mesmerized by the view and architecture of the masjid.
Widespread having capacity to occupy more than 1000 peoples .
A large amount quran with other islamic book available there.
Visited for maghrib prayer , Imam sahab have very beautiful voice .
It's beautiful mosque of Aligarh Muslim University, India.

Nestled within the vibrant campus of Aligarh Muslim University lies the majestic Sir Syed Mosque, a cherished landmark with deep historical roots. Situated within Sir Syed Hall, this mosque not only serves as a place of worship but also holds the revered tomb of Sir Syed Ahmed Khan, the visionary founder of the university. Construction commenced in 1879 under Sir Syed's guidance, culminating in its completion in January 1915. A visit here offers a serene blend of architectural beauty and homage to a pioneering figure in education.
Very beautiful mosque. It is located in sir syed hall south hostel, in Aligarh Uttar pradesh

Inside view Masterpiece of  grand mosque of AMU in terms are Art, peace, and a usual place of gathering for developing wisdom and sense of humbleness. Open to all,  Situated at Victoria gate and Sir Syed south hall, AMU.

places_with_reviews.name: Ghanta Ghar
places_with_reviews.address: V3WF+6HG, Church Compound, Civil Lines, Aligarh, Uttar Pradesh 202001, India

reviews.text: I recommend visiting during the day to fully appreciate its historical beauty. Daytime offers a clearer view and a safer environment, allowing visitors to enjoy the iconic structure without the limitations posed by inadequate lighting.

Aligarh ghanta ghar location is nearby kathpula flyover, church, Aligarh nagar Nigam office, tehseel kol , Railway station is 1 km away from it.
About Aligarh
In 1194, Qutb-ud-din Aibak had mounted a successful invasion of the region and Hisam-ud-din Ulbak was installed as the first Muslim governor; court-historian Hasan Nizami noted Kol to be "one of the most celebrated fortresses of Hind". Beginning the 13th century, the place featured — as Kol or Koil — in multiple Persian (as well as non-Persian)  Sultanate  sources as a center of economic prominence esp. for production of distilled wine. By the mid-13th century, the town commanded enough importance for (would-be Sultan) Ghiyas ud din Balban to erect a minaret.

Under the Khiljis and Tughlaqs, the prominence continued unabated; it had become an  by the times of Alauddin Khalji.

Kol is mentioned in Ibn Battuta's Rihla, when Ibn Battuta, along with 15 ambassadors representing Ukhaantu Khan, emperor of the Mongol Chinese Yuan dynasty, travelled to Kol city en route to the coast at Cambay (in Gujarat) in 1341. According to Battuta, it would appear that the district was then in a very disturbed state since the escort of the Emperor's embassy had to assist in relieving Jalali from an attacking body of Hindus and lost an officer in the fight. Ibn Batuta calls Kol "a fine town surrounded by mango groves". From these same groves the environs of Kol would appear to have acquired the name Sabzabad or "the green country".

In the reign of Akbar, Kol was made a Sirkar and included the dasturs of Marahra, Kol ba Haveli, Thana Farida and Akbarabad.Akbar and Jahangir visited Kol on hunting expeditions. Jahangir clearly mentions the forest of Kol, where he killed wolves.

During the time of Ibrahim Lodhi, Muhammad, son of Umar, was the governor of Kol. He built a fort at Kol and named the city Muhammadgarh, after himself, in 1524–25. Sabit Khan, who was then the governor of this region, rebuilt the old Lodhi fort and named the town Sabitgarh, after himself.

Its a good place for spending your evening either alone or with friends. there are some benches with grass flor that you can opt to sit on. the clock tower, indeed is the main point of this place stands firmly amid the honks of the surrounding running vehicles.

Lovely ambience in the center of crowded city.....
A must place to visit...

It's a nice place for evening walks. This clock tower was erected in 1893 by the voluntary contribution of hindus and mohammedans of Aligarh district. It was named after the then revenue collector Harrison. It was built in victorian Gothic style.
